description.en:
The course is divided into three parts
I - Systems biology: Teach contemporary methods used in systems biology for dynamic modeling. Teach methods for mathematical analysis of biological systems and simulation outputs. Demonstrate how dynamical mathematical models can provide insight that cannot be gained from experiments only.
II - Robotics and computer vision: This part presents an overview of methods for mathematical analysis of robotics in practice and research with topics including vision, motion planning, mobile mechanisms, kinematics, inverse kinematics, and sensors.
III - Integrative approach. Finding and understanding common features in biological and physical engineered dynamic systems.
description.et:
Kursus on jagatud kolmeks osaks
I - süsteemibioloogia: õpetatakse biomolekulaarsete dünaamiliste süsteemide modelleerimise tänapäevaseid meetodeid. Simulatsioonide tulemuse analüüs ja interpreteerimine. Tuuakse näiteid sellest, kuidas dünaamilised matemaatilised mudelid suudavad anda selliseid uusi teadmisi bioloogilistest süsteemidest, mida ei ole võimalik saada vaid eksperimentaalse töö abil.
 II - Robootika: see osa kursusest annab ülevaate matemaatilise analüüsi meetoditest, mida kasutatakse robootikas. 
III - Integreeritud lähenemine. Bioloogiliste ja füüsikaliste dünaamiliste süsteemide ühiste omaduste leidmine ja uurimine.

objectives.en: The overall goal of this course is to train the students in the range of computational approaches that are used in systems biology and engineering. These include (i) analysis of large data sets, (ii) development and analysis of networks, (iii) application of deterministic dynamical models consisting of ordinary or partial differential equations, and (iv) application of stochastic dynamical models, and (v) introduction of robotics toolboxes and simulation of planer movements of robots.
objectives.et: Kursuse peamine eesmärk on treenida üliõpilasi erinevate süsteemibioloogias ja inseneriteaduses kasutatavate arvutuslike meetodite alal. Nendeks on (i) suurte andmehulkade analüüs, (ii) võrgustike arendamine ja analüüs, (iii) harilike ja osaliste differentsiaalvõrrandite baasil loodud deterministlike dünamiliste mudelite rakendamine, (iv) stohhastiliste dünaamiliste mudelite rakendamine, (v) sissejuhatus robootika toolbox'i ja robotite liikumise simulatsioon.

learning_outcomes.en: This is a laboratory course in which the students perform numerical computations during each session and complete problem sets as homework. Students bring their laptop computers to class, and an institutional license allows for MATLAB to be installed on each student's computer. Although the focus of this course is on computational methodologies, the students receive training in the identification of the types of experimental data, the appropriate computational approach for the data set, and the types of questions that can be addressed with a particular data set and computational strategy.
learning_outcomes.et:
Kursuse raames sooritavad üliõpilased arvutusi ja numbrilisi simulatsioone MATLABil arvutiklassis ja teevad vastavasisulisi ülesandeid kodutööna.
Üliõpilased saavad installeerida institutsionaalne MATLABi litsentsi enda sülearvutisse. Kuigi kursuse fookus on suunatud arvutuslikele meetoditele, saavad üliõpilased lisaks kogemusi töös eksperimentaalsete andmete erinevate tüüpide ja kogumitega, ning küsimustes, mida antud andmetega saab lahendada kasutades erinevaid arvutusmeetodeid.

grade_preconditions.et: 70% of practicums should be done in the class (attendance is obligatory)

grade_evaluation.et: 70% of practicums should be done in the class (attendance is obligatory)

description.et:
Introduction. Robot. Definition. Robot anatomy. Robot parts and their functions. Classification of robot and robotic systems. Laws of robotic. Co-ordinate systems. Drives and control systems, Power transmission systems. Planning for navigation. Different applications.
General introduction on the fundamentals of vision cameras and image processing MATLAB toolbox.
An introduction on the fundamental techniques used in computer vision, that is, the analysis of patterns in visual images to reconstruct and understand the objects and scenes that generated them.
Introduction. Light used in machine vision. Basic rules and laws of light distribution. Filters. Light sources. Light techniqueGeneral introduction on different categories of mathematical models. Statistical top down models vs dynamical bottom up models.
Camera technology. Analog and digital camera. Camera model. CCD and CMOS Technology. Sensor size. Intrinsic and extrinsic camera parameters. Camera calibration. Systems of lenses The thin lens. Beam converging and beam diverging lenses. General imaging equation. Aberrations. Practical aspects.
Development of models: Extracting constants from experimental literature and estimating errors.
Ordinary differential equation models of bistability in biochemical signaling. Predicting the bistability. Analysis of two-variable system. Generic example of double-negative feedback loop.
Stability analysis of ODE systems. Stable and unstable fixed points. Jacobian matrix. Nullclines.
Computational modeling of the cell cycle. History and evolution of the Tyson-Novak model. Phenomenological vs mechanistic models.

audience.et: Only for 3rd year Science and Technology bachelor students!
